article: One winter during college in New York, I took an 8 am history class to fulfill a requirement. It was _ to get up for that class, but every morning I would _ the cold winds and went to the lecture. The professor for the class would step _ into the room. He was terribly nervous about the class and always fixed his eyes on his book, never looking up at us. I felt that I needed to do something to _ the boredom, so I tried to find something in his lecture to ask him, _ me to pay attention rather than letting my eyes close. The first time * I raised my hand, he was surprised but was obviously _ to have a question to answer. I continued to do this every day. The professor seemed to become a bit more _ and some other students even joined in. In fact, his answers were always _ . In this way, I learned quite a lot and realized the professor was indeed a/an _ in his field. On the last day of class we _ our books and headed out. The professor stepped directly in front of me, with obvious _ , putting out his hand. He said, " _ you for making my class so interesting," shaking my hand and smiling. I was so _ . To me, it had been a pleasant way to _ the time in his lesson. I had no idea that my _ had any effect on him or the others at all. That _ has stayed with me for 30 years. I don't _ the fact I learned in his class, but I'll never forget the professor who taught me a lesson about the _ of acts of kindness, indeed or not.
